#Text=Henry Wemyss
#Text=Henry Wemyss ( died 1541 ) was a prelate from the 16th century Kingdom of Scotland .
#Text=He appears in the sources in the bishopric of Galloway for the first time in 1517 , and rose to become Bishop of Galloway in 1526 , a position he held until his death in 1541 .
#Text=Biography
#Text=Origin

#Text=He was said to have been the son of John Wemyss , fifth son of Sir John Wemyss of Wemyss , by a daughter of Sir John Arnot of Arnot ( in Fife ) ; if true , this would make him a relative of David Arnot , sometime Bishop of Galloway who resigned that bishopric in Wemyss ' favour ; [ 1 ]
#Text=Robert Keith thought he may have been related to King James V , as a brother , [ 2 ]

#Text=but this was a mistake based on textual misreading ( mispunctuating ) which resulted in Henry 's name being confused with that of James Stewart , Earl of Moray , the King 's actual brother . [ 3 ]
#Text=Earlier career

#Text=Henry is found as the Official of the diocese of Galloway on 8 February 1517 , and again on 16 January 1522 ; the last known holder of this position occurred on 12 March 1512 , so that Henry must have taken this position at some point between 1512 and 1517 . [ 4 ]

#Text=Henry was parson of the parish church of Auchterderran ( Outherdekan ) , Fife , in the diocese of St Andrews , and is found to be Archdeacon of Galloway on 9 December 1522 ; like his position as Official , it not known when he ascended the archdeaconry , and the last occurrence of a predecessor occurs on 9 November 1513 . [ 5 ]
#Text=Bishopric of Galloway
#Text=The letter from Bishop Henry to Abbot William Kennedy of Crossraguel ; Bishop Henry 's signature is visible in the bottom-right .

#Text=Henry Wemyss received provision to the bishopric of Galloway ( with the position of Dean of the Chapel Royal , Stirling ) when David Arnot resigned his bishopric on 23/4 January 1526 ; Arnot retained right of return upon any future vacancy and half of the revenue of the diocese . [ 6 ]

#Text=Although Arnot also resigned his position as Commendator of Tongland for , once again , a lifelong pension and with right of return on vacancy , Arnot may have effectively held on to Tongland Abbey for a few more years ; repeated crown nominations of Wemyss to Tongland failed , apparently because of Arnot , while William Stewart , a canon of Glasgow Cathedral , also got crown nomination until the Pope finally agreed to give Bishop Henry Wemyss Tongland Abbey in commendam in 1530 , with Stewart resigning his rights . [ 7 ]
#Text=The commend of Dundrennan Abbey came into Wemyss ' possession after a crown nomination on 11 December 1529 , to which he was admitted on 24 April 1530 . [ 8 ]
#Text=Henry also retained the Archdeaconry of Galloway after becoming bishop , at least until he resigned the position to Patrick Arnot on 11 February 1531 . [ 9 ]
#Text=Bishop Wemyss was a frequent attender of parliament , and his name occurs frequently as a witness to charters under the Great Seal of Scotland . [ 10 ]
#Text=He appeared for the last time in the latter capacity on 14 March 1541 . [ 10 ]
#Text=He died soon after this date , and was certainly dead by 21 May . [ 11 ]

#Text=On 25 May , Andrew Durie , Abbot of Melrose , was put in charge of the vacant temporalities of Galloway and Tongland ; Durie indeed succeeded Wemyss to these positions later in the year . [ 12 ]
#Text=There survive some correspondences between Bishop Henry Wemyss and William Kennedy , Abbot of Crossraguel , written in the English language . [ 13 ]
#Text=Bishop Henry and Abbot William have been said to have been close friends . [ 14 ]

#Text=Two letters sent by Bishop Wemyss , dated to 5 July , and to 5 December 1536 , survive ; the first was addressed to " Jhone Makmaister and maister Patrik Ryschert " , officials at Crossraguel Abbey , and the second to Abbot William ; they concern certain revenues pertaining to one Ninian Boyd and his land at Culmoyr ( Cùl Mòr , " big back " ) , [ 15 ] over which the bishop may have had rights ; [ 16 ]
#Text=Culmoyr was in the now defunct parish of Clashant , later belonging to the MacDowall kindred of Garthland . [ 17 ]
#Text=Bishop Wemyss ' signature has survived on the letter to Abbot William . [ 18 ]
